Thinking about what your guest said about NOT backing currency in precious 
metal has shifted my Paradigm somewhat. In the Final analysis he is 
correct.. However... I do think it is important to have your currency, 
though, maybe not Backed.. But Certainly Redeemable... And the currency

a Federal Reserve Fractional Banking Note.. (say a fiver) and Analyze what 
it is.. You can only come away confused. The note says that is Five 
Dollars.. But Five Dollars of what? If a bank issues this 5 Dollar Note.. 
It certainly must reference SOMETHING. In the outset, our Government 
defined a Dollar as a measure of Silver. And not only Defined it as such.. 
But made it Redeemable in Silver From the Treasury... I can feel confident 
and saying that the Federal Reserve Notes that we have today are no longer 
Redeemable in anything from the Federal Reserve. The Federal Reserve will 
tell you that you can pay debts or trade the notes for durable goods and 
other products. Simply saying that your currency is redeemable in everyone 
else stuff, but your own, wafts of fraud. I would argue that one of the 
Major functions of any Money.. is that it MUST MAINTAIN ITS VALUE 
CONSISTENTLY for it to be of any use. Any note the Treasure issues can 
fulfilled that requirement so long as it isn't abused. A single oz of 
silver can "back" the entire economy of the US so long as it is ALWAYS more 
Profitable to Keep the Note RATHER Than REDEEM IT... Another Function that 
money SHOULD exhibit is that it must be Transferable... I.E. that when I 
draw my money out of the Bank and I Decide to move to another country..

function. - well just my thoughts.. Keep up the good work...

Most of the world’s money is called fiat money, meaning it is 
accepted as money because a government says that it’s legal tender, and 
the public has enough confidence and faith in the money’s ability to 
serve as a storage medium for purchasing power. 
A fiat system is based on a government’s mandate that the paper currency it 
prints is legal tender for making financial transactions. Legal tender
means that the money is backed by the full faith and credit of the 
government that issues it. In other words, the government promises to be
good for it. 

Fiat money is the opposite of commodity money, which is money 
that’s based on a valuable commodity, a method of valuation that was 
used in the past. At times, the commodity itself actually was used as 
money. For instance, the use of gold, grain, and even furs and other 
animal products as commodity money preceded the current fiat system.﻿

I loved Bill Still's documentary 'The Money Masters'. It was exhaustive and 
I recognise his skills as a documentary maker. However, I do think he's 
extremely naive at times when it comes to human nature and that's 
illustrated by his extremely bizarre support of Donald Trump - a deeply 
unpleasant moral free individual with very obvious criminal ties. 

There's no easy solution here. Bill is correct to suggest that gold and 
silver have historically been concentrated in the hands of the very wealthy 
so he's right to be sceptical about gold backed currencies.

Still's also correct to suggest that democracy is the best thing we've got 
currently and that Ron Paul is a bit of a nut job. Libertarians think that 
small Government and deregulation is the answer but this is obvious madness 
when confronted with a rapacious financial system and extremely powerful 
transnational corporations that rape, and pillage their way around the 
globe. You'd be replacing an admittedly horrible, corrupted Government with 
completely unaccountable private tyrannies and I know which one I'd rather 
have. 

Unfortunately for Bill, he's very naive when it comes to FIAT systems. 
Whilst they can work extremely well for a while, they're eventually 
corrupted by outside sources. The banking system and powerful monied elites 
would eventually get their grubby mitts on the system by bribing officials 
in Government and we're back to square one. There's no easy way out of 
this. 

Humanity has to move on - it has to leave materialism behind, it has to 
leave greed behind, it has to elect politicians that don't promise a quick, 
expedient fix. In fact, humanity has to change it's outlook in order to 
move on and maybe even survive. 

We're killing ourselves and the environment and no one seems to care. A 
collapsing, out of control economic system is just one of many indicators 
that suggests we're circling the drain.﻿

Bill Still is FLAT OUT wrong. The only "money" that works is *PHYSICAL GOLD 
COINS denominated in grams* and *PHYSICAL SILVER COINS denominated in grams* 
and if people wish, *PHYSICAL PLATINUM COINS denominated in grams*.

Frankly, there is no need for silver or platinum to be considered "money" 
at all. In fact, humans can *exchange anything real for anything else real*. 
The primary purpose of an honest *"gold standard"* is simply to establish 
the *exchange rate of all goods and goodies to one standard good (namely 
gold)*. By stating the "price" AKA "exchange rate" of all goods and goodies 
to one standard good (one gram of gold), the *exchange rate of all goods 
and goodies to all other goods and goodies are also established*.

And *THAT* is the purpose of the honest "gold standard". Nobody has to 
exchange gold for goods or goodies. Humans can exchange anything they wish. 
Due to convenience, humans will very often choose to exchange gold coins, 
silver coins (and platinum coins) for goods and goodies, but that's just a 
function of the fact that small disks of inert metals are valuable and are 
easy to carry around and exchange.
